article:
Imagine you have a special kind of liquid called a nematic liquid crystal that's like a magic material that can change its shape when you apply electricity or a magnet. People are really interested in these liquid crystals because they could be used to make cool screens for TVs and phones.

One example of how they work is with a thing called a twisted nematic cell. It's like a little box with two slippery walls that keep the liquid crystal in place. These walls want to align the liquid crystal in a certain way, but they're a bit tricky because they're not all facing the same way. When you give the liquid crystal a little push, it starts to align itself according to the walls.

The surface of the liquid crystal near the walls can be a bit wavy, like a ripple in a pond, because of the way the walls are treated. But don't worry, this wavy part only lasts a short distance, like when you throw a stone in a pool and the ripples fade away. The liquid crystal outside this area behaves like it's on a smooth surface.

People have studied a lot about how the liquid crystal works when it's close to flat surfaces, but what happens when the surfaces have patterns? That's a bit trickier. Some scientists use math and computer simulations to understand these patterns and how they affect the liquid crystal. They've found that by looking at the surface patterns up close, they can predict how the liquid crystal will behave in different situations.

So, the bottom line is, nematic liquid crystals are like magic paint that changes when you touch them just right, and people are trying to learn all the secrets to make them even more useful for our gadgets.
abstract:
we study the phase behavior of a nematic liquid crystal confined between a flat substrate with strong anchoring and a patterned substrate whose structure and local anchoring strength we vary . by first evaluating an effective surface free energy function characterizing the patterned substrate we derive an expression for the effective free energy of the confined nematic liquid crystal . 
 then we determine phase diagrams involving a homogeneous state in which the nematic director is almost uniform and a hybrid aligned nematic state in which the orientation of the director varies through the cell . 
 direct minimization of the free energy functional were performed in order to test the predictions of the effective free energy method . 
 we find remarkably good agreement between the phase boundaries calculated from the two approaches . 
 in addition the effective energy method allows one to determine the energy barriers between two states in a bistable nematic device .

article:
Did you know that galaxy clusters are special groups of stars and space stuff that help us learn about the universe? They're like the biggest mountains in the sky and help scientists understand how things grow and move together. We can see them with different tools, like telescopes, to learn more about them.

Clusters were first noticed a long time ago when people looked at the sky and saw groups of bright stars that didn't belong together. Later, we learned they were not just groups of stars, but big groups of everything, including invisible stuff called dark matter.

Now, we use surveys to find lots of galaxy clusters. Optical surveys, which are like big eye pictures, can find them even if they're not very bright. X-ray surveys can also see the hot, invisible gas inside clusters. By combining these observations, we can learn how much mass is in a cluster and how it's arranged.

There's a bit of a challenge because sometimes we can't see everything clearly, like when the gas is mixed up or there are other things hiding. But scientists are working hard to make sure our pictures and measurements match up, so we can understand what's really happening in those big mountain-like clusters.

article:
Imagine you have a toy box with lights that can work together in special ways, called quantum toys. These lights can become really close and share secrets with each other, even when they're far apart or not at the same time. 

A device called an optical parametric oscillator (OPO) helps create these special connections. It's like a magic box that takes one bright light and makes more lights from it, but not just one or two, lots of them! 

In this magic box, there's a special crystal inside that makes the lights interact and become even closer, like when you play with building blocks. This is what creates something called "squeezing" and "entanglement." Squeezing is when the light becomes extra quiet in some parts, and entanglement is when the lights are connected in a way that they know what the other is doing.

Now, imagine if the toy box had a pattern on its surface that changes how the lights behave. This pattern is like a map that guides the lights differently. Scientists have shown that if they put this pattern in the OPO, they can make the lights even more connected and quiet, almost like they have their own secret language.

They did some math and simulations to prove this, and they found out that by changing the pattern, they could control how much the lights share their secrets with each other. They did this with a special kind of OPO called a photonic crystal optical parametric oscillator (PCopo), which is a fancy name for the magic box with the pattern.

So, the researchers studied how the pattern affects the lights' actions and how well they stay connected, and they shared their results in a paper. This could help make future technology with these quantum lights even better!
abstract:
we show how to control spatial quantum correlations in a multimode degenerate optical parametric oscillator type i below threshold by introducing a spatially inhomogeneous medium , such as a photonic crystal , in the plane perpendicular to light propagation . 
 we obtain the analytical expressions for all the correlations in terms of the relevant parameters of the problem and study the number of photons , entanglement , squeezing , and twin beams . considering different regimes and configurations we show the possibility to tune the instability thresholds as well as the quantumness of correlations by breaking the translational invariance of the system through a photonic crystal modulation .

article:
Okay, imagine you have a story about special water droplets called "methanol masers" that help us learn about how stars are born. These masers can be found in places where baby stars are making their home, like in a big cloud of gas and dust.

There are two types of methanol masers: Class I and Class II. Class I masers, like the 36 and 44 GHz ones, are thought to be excited by tiny bumps and collisions, while Class II masers, like the 6.7 and 12 GHz ones, are excited by light. Sometimes, both types are found together, but they don't always show up at the same place or at the same speed.

Class I masers are believed to be a little older than the other types. We've been studying them mostly in places that already show signs of star birth, but the places where they live can be tricky to understand. We use special dishes to look at them, but they can't see where the masers are exactly or how they're connected to the exciting sources.

Now, a team of scientists did a special search using really good dishes, called EVLA, to find more Class I methanol masers. They looked at a place called DR21, where lots of baby stars are forming. They found 49 masers, mostly in two of the parts, and they noticed that some of them are close to other masers they found before.

The team also saw that the 36 GHz masers, which are one type they studied, form a sort of circle with other masers they've seen before. Some are moving together, like they're all part of a group. They also found that the 6.7 GHz masers, another type, are right above a bright spot, almost like they're sitting on top of it.

The team hopes that by looking closely at these masers, they can learn more about how stars grow and change. But there's still more to discover, and they need even better tools to understand everything perfectly.
abstract:
class  i methanol masers are believed to be produced in the shock - excited environment around star - forming regions . 
 many authors have argued that the appearance of various subsets of class  i masers may be indicative of specific evolutionary stages of star formation or excitation conditions . until recently , however , no major interferometer was capable of imaging the important 36  ghz transition . 
 we report on expanded very large array observations of the 36  ghz methanol masers and submillimeter array observations of the 229  ghz methanol masers in dr21(oh ) , dr21n , and dr21w . 
 the distribution of 36  ghz masers in the outflow of dr21(oh ) is similar to that of the other class  i methanol transitions , with numerous multitransition spatial overlaps . 
 at the site of the main continuum source in dr21(oh ) , class  i masers at 36 and 229  ghz are found in virtual overlap with class  ii 6.7  ghz masers . to the south of the outflow 
 , the 36  ghz masers are scattered over a large region but usually do not appear coincident with 44  ghz masers . 
 in dr21w we detect an `` s - curve '' signature in stokes v that implies a large value of the magnetic field strength if interpreted as due to zeeman splitting , suggesting either that class  i masers may exist at higher densities than previously believed or that the direct zeeman interpretation of s - curve stokes v profiles in class  i masers may be incorrect . 
 we find a diverse variety of different maser phenomena in these sources , suggestive of differing physical conditions among them .

article:
Imagine you have a big puzzle where scientists from different areas like physics, chemistry, and biology work together to solve problems. Recently, this teamwork has become very important and has led to some amazing discoveries. Some people are trying to find a way to measure how well these different areas are connected in their work, like how much a science project influences other fields.

Some grown-ups have tried to make rules for this teamwork, like special projects that ask people to work across different subjects. They even have ways to decide who is the best at connecting ideas from different places. But, it's hard to tell if someone is really good at this because we don't have a good way to measure it yet.

This work wants to create a tool that shows how much a scientist's work or a paper is connected to different areas. It's like giving them a score that shows how much they bridge different subjects. They use a special way to look at a big network of scientists, their papers, and the connections between them. This network has different parts, like one for physics, one for biology, and so on.

They use a computer program called "pagerank" to figure out which papers and scientists are the most versatile, meaning they touch many areas. This way, we can see who is doing a great job of working across different fields. They tested their method with two examples: one with lots of physics papers and another with patents. These examples helped show that their tool works well.

In simple terms, this research wants to find a way to tell if a scientist or a paper is really good at connecting different areas of science, like a桥梁 between physics and biology.
abstract:
nowadays , scientific challenges usually require approaches that cross traditional boundaries between academic disciplines , driving many researchers towards interdisciplinarity . despite its obvious importance , there is a lack of studies on how to quantify the influence of interdisciplinarity on the research impact , posing uncertainty in a proper evaluation for hiring and funding purposes . here 
 we propose a method based on the analysis of bipartite interconnected multilayer networks of citations and disciplines , to assess scholars , institutions and countries interdisciplinary importance . 
 using data about physics publications and us patents , we show that our method allows to reward , using a quantitative approach , scholars and institutions that have carried out interdisciplinary work and have had an impact in different scientific areas . 
 the proposed method could be used by funding agencies , universities and scientific policy decision makers for hiring and funding purposes , and to complement existing methods to rank universities and countries .

article:
Did you know that grown-up scientists have learned a lot about how making things grow and getting them really, really cold affects the special magnets in some materials? These materials, called (III,Mn)V diluted magnetic semiconductors, are like building blocks that can become really strong and conduct electricity when they're just right. 

Before, we used a simple model to explain how these materials work, like how the tiny parts called holes in the semiconductor talk to the special Mn atoms that have a tiny spin. When everything is neat and clean, this model works well and helps us understand things like how the magnets get stronger or why they behave a certain way.

Now, we're looking at how these materials change when they're not perfectly perfect. We're using math to figure out how tiny mistakes or imperfections, like when the Mn atoms don't sit in just the right place, affect the special light and magnetic properties. This helps us learn more about the true nature of these materials and how they might be used in things like smart devices in the future.

We're going to talk about some cool things we've found, like how the material's behavior changes when it gets a little warm or how it looks in the infrared, which is a special kind of light. By comparing what we see with our calculations, we hope to understand the material better and maybe find ways to make it even better for our purposes.
abstract:
we present a theoretical study of the infrared magneto - optical properties of ferromagnetic ( iii , mn)v semiconductors . our analysis combines the kinetic exchange model for ( iii , mn)v ferromagnetism with kubo linear response theory and born approximation estimates for the effect of disorder on the valence band quasiparticles . 
 we predict a prominent feature in the ac - hall conductivity at a frequency that varies over the range from 200 to 400 mev , depending on mn and carrier densities , and is associated with transitions between heavy - hole and light - hole bands . in its zero frequency limit , our hall conductivity reduces to the @xmath0-space berry s phase value predicted by a recent theory of the anomalous hall effect that is able to account quantitatively for experiment . 
 we compute theoretical estimates for magnetic circular dichroism , faraday rotation , and kerr effect parameters as a function of mn concentration and free carrier density . 
 the mid - infrared response feature is present in each of these magneto - optical effects .

article:
Okay, imagine you're playing with building blocks to understand how stars work. Stars are like big balls that pull on each other very strongly, but sometimes, at really close distances, they don't behave exactly right according to how we learned from simpler rules. So, we make a little change to the rules, called "softening," to fix this problem.

Softening is like giving the blocks a little buffer, so they don't stick too close together. But how much buffer we need can vary depending on how we want to play with the blocks. Different types of buffers are used in different games, and we want to make sure they all work well together.

We've looked at different ways to make the blocks softer, like using different shapes or sizes. We found that just the right amount of buffer makes the game more realistic and helps us understand how the stars move properly. This is important because it affects how the blocks, or stars, settle down after a big shake-up.

Now, we're going to study these different buffer settings and see how they affect the game. We'll compare the games with 2D blocks (like a flat sheet) and 3D blocks (with space around them). We'll also look at how the blocks move when they spin, and how they behave when we try to balance them.

Our goal is to find the perfect balance, or the "sweet spot" for the buffer size that gives us the most accurate picture of how real stars work. This will help us design better experiments and understand the universe better, just like figuring out the best way to stack the blocks.
abstract:
two questions that naturally arise in @xmath0-body simulations of stellar systems are :    1 
 .   how can we compare experiments that employ different types of softened gravity ? 
 2 .   given a particular type of softened gravity , which choices of the softening length optimize the faithfulness of the experiments to the newtonian dynamics ?    
 we devise a method for exploring the dynamical effects of softening , which provides detailed answers in the case of 2-d simulations of disc galaxies and also solves important aspects of the 3-d problem . in the present paper we focus on two applications that reveal the dynamical differences between the most representative types of softened gravity , including certain anisotropic alternatives . 
 our method is potentially important not only for testing but also for developing new ideas about softening . 
 indeed , it opens a _ direct _ route to the discovery of optimal types of softened gravity for given dynamical requirements , and thus to the accomplishment of a physically consistent modelling .

article:
Spinfoams are special math pictures used to study a thing called loop quantum gravity. They help us understand how tiny parts of space move around. In spinfoams, we use special shapes with lines and dots to represent how these parts fit together. We talk about spins and little pieces called intertwiners that connect these lines.

When we change the way we draw our spinfoams, we get different ways to understand them. One way is like a game where we imagine moving a connection thing called the Ashtekar connection along the lines. Another way uses special numbers called holomorphic variables that come from something called the Segal-Bargmann transform.

These different ways might look different, but they all give us the same information about the space. They help us find patterns and learn more about how space works at very small scales.

In this paper, we explore two special ways to draw spinfoams - the "holonomy representation" and the "holomorphic representation." These new ways make it easier to understand how spinfoams behave when we look at them close to how things look in everyday life. We use these representations to study big spaces and see how they match up with our understanding of classical geometry, which is how space looks without tiny quantum effects.
abstract:
we study a holomorphic representation for spinfoams . the representation is obtained via the ashtekar - lewandowski - marolf - mouro - thiemann coherent state transform . 
 we derive the expression of the 4d spinfoam vertex for euclidean and for lorentzian gravity in the holomorphic representation . 
 the advantage of this representation rests on the fact that the variables used have a clear interpretation in terms of a classical intrinsic and extrinsic geometry of space . 
 we show how the peakedness on the extrinsic geometry selects a single exponential of the regge action in the semiclassical large - scale asymptotics of the spinfoam vertex .

article:
Have you ever seen toy cars moving on a track? Imagine a little race where some cars can only go one way, and sometimes they switch to another lane to keep moving. Researchers have been studying a simple model called "Driven Diffusive Systems" that behaves like this, especially a model called "Asymmetric Simple Exclusion Processes" (ASEPs). These models help us understand how things like molecules move around in cells.

ASEPs are used in many things, like helping tiny machines called molecular motors move along thin strings inside cells, just like how your toy cars follow tracks. They've even been used to study how things move in traffic-like situations.

A special kind of ASEP is called "Totally Asymmetric Simple Exclusion Process" (TASEP), which is the simplest version. It helps us understand how particles, like tiny balls, move in a straight line. Scientists have looked at how these particles move when there are more or fewer of them, and how they change lanes.

Recently, researchers made a model that includes more details, like how particles can attach or detach from the tracks. This is called the "PFF Model." They found that when particles move and change lanes, sometimes they jump back and forth, creating a special kind of movement that's not always straight. This is called the "jumping effect."

They also discovered that the speed of the tracks, or how fast the particles move, changes depending on how many particles are on the track. When there are too many, it gets slower! And when they added extra rules for the particles to change lanes, they saw even more interesting patterns.

In a two-lane version of the model, where cars can switch lanes, the researchers found that the movement of the track walls, which separate the lanes, can also change direction. This is like the cars sometimes going left and then right. They call this the "jumping effect," and it's affected by how fast the particles can attach and detach.

These models help us learn how things really happen in cells and how they move around, making them very important for understanding biological processes and even traffic flow.
abstract:
in this paper , we study a two - lane totally asymmetric simple exclusion process ( tasep ) coupled with random attachment and detachment of particles ( langmuir kinetics ) in both lanes under open boundary conditions . 
 our model can describe the directed motion of molecular motors , attachment and detachment of motors , and free inter - lane transition of motors between filaments . in this paper 
 , we focus on some finite - size effects of the system because normally the sizes of most real systems are finite and small ( e.g. , size @xmath0 ) . 
 a special finite - size effect of the two - lane system has been observed , which is that the density wall moves left first and then move towards the right with the increase of the lane - changing rate . 
 we called it the jumping effect . 
 we find that increasing attachment and detachment rates will weaken the jumping effect . 
 we also confirmed that when the size of the two - lane system is large enough , the jumping effect disappears , and the two - lane system has a similar density profile to a single - lane tasep coupled with langmuir kinetics . 
 increasing lane - changing rates has little effect on density and current after the density reaches maximum . also , lane - changing rate has no effect on density profiles of a two - lane tasep coupled with langmuir kinetics at a large attachment / detachment rate and/or a large system size . 
 mean - field approximation is presented and it agrees with our monte carlo simulations .

article:
CC method is a way to solve a big math problem about how many tiny particles work together. It uses a special idea to write the wave function, like a recipe for how the particles move. We'll talk about it a bit and then make the math simpler.

Imagine you have a bunch of building blocks, and the CC method tries to find the best way to arrange them. To do this, it uses a special kind of guess, called the cluster operator, which is like arranging blocks into different patterns. We need to find the right sizes and positions for these patterns.

The CC method starts with a simple idea, but when we try to calculate how these patterns work together, the math gets very long and tricky. That's where the problem comes - there are lots and lots of steps, but only a few of them are needed in the end. 

To fix this, we want to add up some of the steps without counting them twice. We're going to do this in a smart way, just like how you might count your toys without overcounting. We'll use a special way to dress up the building blocks, making the math look prettier and more accurate.

We'll use this dressed-up CC method to study something called the hyperfine structure constant and the dipole matrix elements for a specific atom, called Cs. This is like figuring out how the atoms behave in a special way. We'll show how this works in the math and compare it to other ways people have done it before.

In simple terms, we're trying to make the math for how atoms act work even better, so we can learn more about them!
abstract:
we consider evaluation of matrix elements with the coupled - cluster method . 
 such calculations formally involve infinite number of terms and we devise a method of partial summation ( dressing ) of the resulting series . 
 our formalism is built upon an expansion of the product @xmath0 of cluster amplitudes @xmath1 into a sum of @xmath2-body insertions . 
 we consider two types of insertions : particle / hole line insertion and two - particle / two - hole random - phase - approximation - like insertion . 
 we demonstrate how to `` dress '' these insertions and formulate iterative equations . 
 we illustrate the dressing equations in the case when the cluster operator is truncated at single and double excitations . using univalent systems as an example , we upgrade coupled - cluster diagrams for matrix elements with the dressed insertions and highlight a relation to pertinent fourth - order diagrams . 
 we illustrate our formalism with relativistic calculations of hyperfine constant @xmath3 and @xmath4 electric - dipole transition amplitude for cs atom . finally , we augment the truncated coupled - cluster calculations with otherwise omitted fourth - order diagrams . 
 the resulting analysis for cs is complete through the fourth - order of many - body perturbation theory and reveals an important role of triple and disconnected quadruple excitations .
